3709.54.text: And I think all of us get involved in

3719.28.text: in organisations, do try and get out into workplaces,

3724.19.text: but I think we've got to cascade that through

3726.29.text: all the organisation and make sure that managers

3731.09.text: in the middle of the organisation are

3734.46.text: having the conversations with the people doing the

3738.17.text: work - finding out what worked well, what did not

3743.11.text: go according to plan or was difficult or frustrating,

3746.64.text: what could have gone better, and what can

3749.18.text: we do to improve things around here. And I think

3753.65.text: if we take an interest in the understandings

3765.96.text: that people in the workplace have and take as much

3770.07.text: of an understanding as those early players like

3774.20.text: Barr, Legg and Augusta Zadow did, then we'll be

3779.71.text: all right and we will make a big difference. Thank you.

3792.86.text: Thank you Dennis. We have time for a couple of questions.

3796.06.text: So if anyone has a question, if they could raise their hand.

3800.63.text: Yes, down the end here. If you just wait for the

3806.37.text: David Segrott, Australian Health and Safety Services.

3811.21.text: Dennis, I'm interested in your move forward just

3815.61.text: from the management systems approach into adaptation,

3820.08.text: yet what I'm seeing happen is a resurgence of the management

3825.19.text: systems approach, where there is a significantly high level

3829.36.text: of focus on the paperwork, audits, compliance,

3833.80.text: rather than the focus on the actual identification

3837.83.text: and management of hazards and risks in workplace more so.

3841.97.text: And I'd be interested in your comments on the challenge

3846.41.text: that that presents in actually making the move forward.

3851.31.text: Well, I think it is a big challenge because we

3855.52.text: have a society that we've managed to lull into a

3861.39.text: sense of comfort that having all these paperwork

3865.56.text: systems is making a big difference, and I'm not

3869.47.text: trying to imply that it hasn't been important,

3873.20.text: I'm sure it has, but it's the ability to now simplify,

3879.64.text: to reduce the amount of them. Now the hard work

3884.51.text: starts because you've actually got to make the

3887.15.text: hard decisions as to how you can make this more effective,

3893.76.text: which things are you prepared not to have

3896.76.text: a lot of rules about, how do you resist the

3902.27.text: temptation to respond to an incident by adding to

3908.34.text: the administrative arrangements around that job

3913.11.text: when in fact you really know the job will get done

3915.95.text: the way the job was done before, but you can walk

3918.85.text: away feeling comfortable that, "Well I've tried."

3922.89.text: Now, I think it's harder, this area of accepting

3929.83.text: that there is adaption and the safety too,

3934.70.text: is actually harder. But I think we'll find that

3937.97.text: people in workplaces will be surprised that

3943.17.text: we are talking about reality again.

3953.52.text: Hello Dennis. Mick Peterson. Dennis, just a question

3957.62.text: about how we can share our successes and our failures

3962.39.text: better across industries and within industries,

3965.80.text: and who should be driving those sorts of processes?

3971.67.text: That almost sounds like a Dorothy Dix. I've spent

3977.04.text: years trying to get a process whereby there is a

3982.51.text: sharing of the innovations between organisations

3986.28.text: and I think that I'm almost coming to the point

3992.09.text: now of realising that perhaps things don't -

4000.43.text: it's more what happens within an organisation than

4004.23.text: seeing something come from outside. I think now

4008.87.text: having worked for the last eight years in one

4012.14.text: organisation trying to effect change, I have

4016.15.text: lesser belief that codifying and producing good

4021.38.text: ideas amongst people that are already very busy

4027.69.text: will actually get picked up and used. And so I put

4032.33.text: much more effort now into teasing out the

4037.63.text: 'few' from the 'many', and then putting a lot more effort

4041.84.text: into how do we get the conversations to take

4046.51.text: place around these learnings? And I think that's

4050.75.text: been a shift in me over the last eight years

4054.62.text: whereas before I thought, "If we could just capture all

4057.72.text: these good ideas obviously, people will pick

4060.46.text: them up and use them." It's nowhere near as easy as that.

4065.06.text: Thank you. I think we have a question over here.

4069.43.text: Yes. Wendy Alford. I'm a Futurist and Ergonomist.

4072.74.text: My question is about wellness to illness as a

4075.87.text: continuum and if it's context defined. So, if you're

4079.44.text: looking for zero harm, we're going to have a

4081.21.text: problem I guess, shifting people towards understanding

4085.45.text: that if you're not sick, how well are you?

4089.15.text: And how can we put the resources in when everybody's

4091.65.text: trying to close the system, through I guess,

4097.63.text: missing injury when promoting wellness is actually

4101.76.text: quite an expensive thing as well. There's a lot

4104.83.text: of gains to be made and zero harm I think is going

4108.14.text: to be something that we'll have to be realistic about.

4112.11.text: Yes. I think the words you used there, "zero harm"

4116.05.text: is something we have to be realistic about

4118.05.text: is really important because I think laudable,

4122.72.text: as the aims are, and I think there are proponents

4125.79.text: that we'll have - able to articulate the strength

4130.89.text: of it. I find that there is a challenge of people

4141.50.text: not believing that that fits with the reality of

4146.11.text: the lives they see on a daily basis - you know -

4149.95.text: and I remember there was work done by Dunphy and

4152.88.text: Stace looking across many Australian organisations

4157.65.text: and they came to the conclusion that health and

4160.12.text: safety was often used as the litmus test by people

4165.90.text: in the organisation as whether the mouthings of

4169.53.text: senior people about, "People are our biggest asset,"

4173.50.text: or whatever - whether it was real or not

4176.07.text: because they could see, "What am I being delivered

4178.91.text: on a daily basis compared to what I'm hearing?"

4182.21.text: And I think that that's one of the issues with

4186.75.text: zero harm, that you're often expressing a view

4191.65.text: about it, but what people are seeing on a daily

4194.52.text: basis, may be a bit of a dissonance there. I think

4199.80.text: it's more important that we focus on sort of very

4205.27.text: serious harm because I think that resonates more

4208.80.text: with people. And I think the other part of your question,

4211.54.text: in terms of how do you have an impact on some

4214.18.text: of those other wellness issues, I would not

4217.78.text: underestimate how important being heard is in

4223.82.text: terms of wellness, and just listening honestly to

4228.39.text: people about the real work they do and valuing

4233.66.text: them as specialists in whatever it is they do.

4238.70.text: They're always specialists in some small part of

4242.40.text: the business processes and ought to be recognised

4247.51.text: for that. I think we often miss a huge opportunity

4253.95.text: to increase the wellness of an organisation and

4257.12.text: certainly in the Brookfield Multiplex organisation

4261.66.text: we run opinion surveys every couple of years and

4267.36.text: I've inserted a whole range of questions in there

4269.90.text: which relate to whether people feel that they're

4273.20.text: being listened to, and if they have issues,

4276.74.text: can they rely on someone acting on them because if

4279.44.text: they can't, I don't think we're living up to some

4286.68.text: of the value statements that we make.

4293.42.text: Terrific. Well thank you very much Dennis for

4299.13.text: I was particularly fascinated by your discussions

4301.43.text: about the different ages in health and safety and

4303.70.text: the advances that have been made. I think it's

4306.04.text: really important that we look back at the

4307.57.text: technical and scientific developments and the

4309.84.text: human factors and management systems which have

4313.14.text: contributed to improvements in health and safety.

4316.51.text: But I think you've also reminded us that we need

4318.71.text: to engage with the adaptive age, and that is how

4322.79.text: we tackle health and safety issues in the

4325.15.text: workplace, and we must always increasingly

4327.72.text: constantly evolve to meet the challenges of an

4330.56.text: increasingly complex world, but importantly you

4333.80.text: have talked about the importance of communication.

4335.80.text: I think that's always a good thing to remember.

4338.17.text: So, to all of you out there, don't forget that you

4340.64.text: can view this and other videos that showcase the

4343.47.text: latest work health and safety thinking, research

4346.04.text: and innovations during the Virtual Seminar Series

4348.54.text: on the Safe Work Australia website. Thank you.
